I've played a few different thematic variations of Fluxx, so I don't know where exactly to leave this rating. Really it doesn't matter because it all winds up at the same chaotic disaster of an experience. I don't get it. I just do not get this game. I love simple games. I can have fun and laugh at a game that doesn't take itself seriously, where it's more like a social activity. Telestrations. Boom. Takes 5 seconds to explain. Everyone gets it. You laugh and all walks of life can participate. And if you don't like it, you can clearly see when the game will end (which also doesn't take long). But Fluxx is the only game on this planet that I might refuse to play from this day forward. It's billed as a silly game for non-gamers, but how can such a convoluted, confusing, random, potentially endless game make for an enjoyable experience for those new to the hobby? I hate that this game is being recommended to friends of mine that have a casual interest in games and stumble wide-eyed into a store for the first time. I never intended to rate this game as it clearly isn't meant for me and I don't want to be super negative. But after having to teach this game to friends who couldn't figure out how to play from reading the rules, I needed to air my grievances with Fluxx. THERE ARE SO MANY OTHER GREAT GAMES. Don't make someone suffer through this one.

Why I find Fluxx so horrible? Well I've played three games, the first one lasted for 30 minutes without me even getting to play a single card. In the second one, I got to play but was out of luck and couldn't win on my turn. So before I had a chance to play again, someone took a 10 minute turn and won. Again we played for 30 minutes, during which I contributed for a single massive minute. The third game was the same as the second one.

So, I've lost 90 minutes of my life to Fluxx, and of that time I was active only for a couple of minutes. There were almost no decisions to be made. Once you figured out in which order to play your cards, you only played what you could and hoped for the best.

Fluxx brings you one of the worst fun-to-time ratios, hands down. After 2008 I have simply refused to play on all occasions, which are scarce (thank god for this) and limited to the biggest of conventions that seem to attract the weirdest of weirdos who enjoy playing all the bad games just for the sake of it. I find the whole concept similar to watching movies that are so bad that, in some perverse way beyond my comprehension, are "good".

I thought Munchkin would be my most disliked game, because of its randomness and longevity, but I am sorely mistaken. Fluxx (and any version, as the concept is the same) is by far the worst game I have ever played. Do you want a game that you can win on the first turn? Do you like party games that can last for over two hours? Do you like complete randomness in your games? If you answered yes to all three of those questions, Fluxx is still not the game for you because you can go play Munchkin, which I hate to say, is 10 times better than Fluxx. The basics of Fluxx is to complete the current goal (which constantly changes), by having a pair of cards in front of you that matches the goal. That's it. Now add cards that changes the goal constantly, changes drawing and discarding rules, the fact that you can only play one card per turn, you only draw one card (initially) per turn, and every type of card is in a SINGLE draw deck, and you've go yourself the most random game know to man. Awful game, I cannot be bribed any amount of money to play this again.

The core 'collect a set of items or modify the shared state so you win' has been done better by Looney in Chrononauts, where attaching some of the elements here to a more concrete and more entertaining setting which ties more satisfyingly to what you're actually doing in the game (rather than being merely artwork, as it is in the various Fluxx variants).

This game sounds great on paper, but in practice is not at all fun. If I win, there's no sense of accomplishment since victory conditions change arbitrarily and far too fast to make decisions around. If I lose, I'm still frustrated because my opponents didn't earn a victory either. Some of the themes expansions like Star Fluxx improve upon that problem mildly by adding more persisting effects, but even then the fundamental premise is still that you have no real control over the game and everything is constantly changing, which really just turns it into an exercise in boredom and frustration without a payoff.

Fluxx is a series very near and dear to my heart, but adding some sort of more cohesive theme to the game does wonders for it. Any other version of Fluxx is better than this, but I hold no negative feeling toward the original.
Pray that someone can end the game early or you might be stuck on this game for a while.

I suspect Fluxx was born out of a desire to see MTG's promise ("card text can change any rule") realised to a greater potential. And the base framework is here, but the card design is overall just silly and swingy with no sense or reason. There are simply too many potential victory conditions and too many crazy wild swings for anything but purely opportunistic play to prevail; once the "ah, I see" of how cards interact has been explored, nothing's really here to hold interest. The solution from the publisher's perspective is, of course, a bazillion additional and equally silly versions/expansions to maintain that exploratory phase alive (and profits rolling).

Sessions can end in 30 seconds or really overstay their welcome within the 30 min territory, including excruciating (for your opponents) turns of optimising the draw/play of over a dozen cards. Still shorter than Munchkin.
I feel like I'm caught between a rock and a hard place of not wanting to be the guy on a high horse who can't enjoy a silly card game like Fluxx, but who also just really does not enjoy Fluxx...

Played again recently and reminded me of everything that frustrated me about it. My biggest gripe is unlike practically every other game I’ve ever played, there’s no guarantee of progress toward an ending. You could win on your first turn, or be playing for the rest of your life, there’s really no way to be sure. OK, typically it ends rather quickly. But when it doesn’t, the knowledge that it doesn’t need to end, ever, seeps into your gut like a creeping horror.

Basically this game is what happens when the power of a single turn is turned up to 11. There are amazing plays to be made, but if you can’t win, the state of the game when it returns to you will be unrecognizable. You have to hold onto your best cards in the hope you can use them on your next turn, but you also need to make sure no one else is holding anything useful, so your opponents will be doing their best to destroy everything you have before your next turn, and it’s not hard to do.

Winning can either happen by pure luck or by eventually letting your opponents’ greed or impatience get the better of them, as they pass up an opportunity to destroy you in order to preserve themselves. Although there’s a certain grim satisfaction in the latter it doesn’t make up for the general feeling of bashing your head on a wall, in my book.

I won't argue that some people could enjoy this game, but it's really not for me. It's meant to be a wacky, swingy game full of hilarious crazy rules that continually change. In many ways it feels like a parody of a traditional card game, but the constantly changing goals of the game and abundance of targeted and ruthless cards make it impossible to do any sort of engine building or even get closer to winning as the game progresses.
-The game makes you feel like you can influence the direction of the game in your favor, but %90-95 of the time you wind up frustrated that the game doesn't even look the same by the time it got back to you. The entire goals of the game may have changed, rendering that plan you had useless, so you have to start from scratch (as if you had just started the game).
-I'm actually a fan of wacky, luck-driven games (quacks of quedlinburg,6 nimmt, King of Tokyo). This just goes too far.

I think any game can be fun with the right group and the right mindset. That being said, some games facilitate a quality shared experience better than others. This game continually does a very poor job of this compared to many other games.

This was a really excellent stepping stone to have available on my journey into the hobby, but I just can't tolerate playing it much more. At anything but 2P, planning beyond your current hand is basically useless. It can somehow slog (you drew 5 played 5 and nothing really came of it? / we made it to a full deck reshuffle?). I can actually tolerate the randomness -- if anything it's sort of the joy of the experience -- but most of the cards are more "atomic" effects than lending themselves to more *emergent* experiences, so the sense of discovery wanes after a handful of plays in the Fluxx system.

All that said and this would rank fine alongside the Exploding Kittenses of the world. But for some reason this game seems to make the people who win feel clever and that evokes a strong annoyance in me. I don't have an emotional attachment to winning Fluxx, nor, despite the theatrics I often take up while acting as a game avatar, do I really have personal attachment to my win-loss ratio in ANY games. But for some reason having this chaotic experience and then seeing satisfaction in the winner's eyes triggers an unusual grumpiness in me, like watching a silver-spooned triply-safety-netted individual talking about the American dream and how they just "put their nose down" and "made their own success".

So yes, it's a me problem. I can't fully engage the "I'm playing Uno with my family" mode in my brain. But I'm not going to rate this on some platonic ideal of other people's experiences. So there. That is my... 3 paragraph analysis of a silly family card game.

Rereading this, maybe it isn't quite fair to call that grumpiness "unusual"...

The core concept of Fluxx appeals to me - an extremely minimal card game whose rules are made more elaborate and complex by the very cards that are played - but the execution feels lackluster. It's extremely chaotic & the rules changes are difficult to plan around, not to mention the highly variable game-length... but the chaos is sort of the point. What I take more issue with is the fact that many of the cards are just not very interesting. A huge portion of them are the so-called "keepers", cards which you put in front of you and have no effect of their own. Almost all of the objectives are just a pair of keepers you need to acquire. Many of the rules cards just change how many cards you can draw or play. The few cards that actually do something interesting usually involve some random element, or affect all players the same way, which makes it hard to judge how useful they are. At times dull and at others confusing, but never all that interesting. Still, Fluxx is wild enough to keep my interest for a short time.

A lot of people hate Fluxx and not without reason: this is a totally absurd and senseless luckfest where even tactical planning is almost impossible. Yet, I find it funny.

The rules are simple: each turn you draw a card and you play a card. Possible cards can be either rules, which alter the draw/play ratio along with some other things, actions, which have an immediate effect, keepers, which are objects that you keep in front of you, and goals, which are put into play and the first player that has the keepers displayed on the goal wins.

The game for the most part plays itself, but leads to funny situations and only last ten minutes... But sometimes drags. And drags. And drags. And that's what can make a game of Fluxx really stink, because a quick and light filler turns into a senseless activity that doesn't seem to end. Indeed, it can drag over an hour or even more, though that's unlikely.

My suggestion is that you pull it out in "beer & pretzels" situations, but play with the house rule that if the game isn't over after 10-15 minutes, everyone looses.

Chaos abounds, and that's a good thing. You've probably seen, and likely played, this in at least one of its flavors. And there are many. It is light and simple.

Fluxx is simple: Everyone gets 3 cards, and one player starts by drawing a card and playing a card. There are no limits and no other rules, until there are. And therein lies the beauty in the game's simplicity. Goals, Keepers (the means of achieving the goals), Actions, and New Rules are in the cards.

In minutes you may find yourself drawing 4 cards, being able to play 2, and having a hand size of only 1, with the first card you play being randomly selected from your hand, all as you hope to win the lottery (Dreams+Money).

Setup and re-boxing times are essentially immaterial. You pull a basic rules card, shuffle up, deal, and start. Don't expect depth of strategy here, though, as luck and some silliness will likely determine the winner.

Fluxx is a quasi-chaotic game where the rules are always changing... in other words, it’s not a very serious game. In fact, the best part of playing Fluxx is seeing all the funny combinations of keepers listed on the goal cards.

This is the plain vanilla version of Fluxx, so the “jokes” formed by the keepers and goal cards are more basic and easy to understand (e.g., the goal “melted chocolate” requires the keepers “chocolate” and “the Sun”). This game is ok, and a good way to introduce the game to a broad audience, but it lacks the zing of the more tightly themed versions, like Star Trek Fluxx or Firefly Fluxx, etc.

I recently watched an interview with the designer Andy Looney which explained a lot! He possesses a special kind of genius.

Fluxx gets a lot of stick for being random. It isn't just random, it is chaotic, stressful and frequently utterly mental.

Basically the game rules can (and very often will) significantly change from turn to turn based on the cards played. One turn you could be drawing a card and playing a card in the pursuit of launching a rocket to the moon, the next turn you could be drawing 5 cards and playing 10, playing rock, paper scissors with an opponent, drawing MORE cards if it's your birthday and playing random cards from the deck to try and combine milk and cookies.....

I don't really understand the criticism because Fluxx, in my opinion, does exactly what it sets out to do, and that is provide an unusual, chaotic game experience where nobody really knows what is going to happen which doesn't feel like any other game. And surely there's a place for a game like that in most peoples lives? No? Do you need a special kind of mind to appreciate it? Do I only like Fluxx because secretly I just want to watch the world burn? Maybe. But it has achieved mainstream popularity, which is surprising.


Some people have said that the game is so chaotic that it's hardly a game at all and that you just play cards until somebody lucks into a victory condition. I suppose it could be played that way but I have definitely won more games than I have lost and the top players on BGA would definitely disagree. There is always a chance that a beginner could beat a master, that's part of the chaos which is part of the charm but equally a good player knows how to create opportunities for themselves whilst limiting the choices of their opponents.

I think Fluxx is a beautiful, complex and misunderstood game which could be enjoyed by all, so long as everyone agrees to enjoy it for what it is, rather than complaining about what it isn't,

The craziness has been given a physical form! While the idea is quite simple, the fact that you can change how the game is played on the get go is quite entertaining. No two games are the same.
The only detail is that it requires a lot of attention.

Fluxx is a simple game full of random things happening. While playing you constantly change the rules. How many cards are drawn? How many are played? What is the limit of cards in your hand? What is the winning condition? This is what makes Fluxx fun. If you want a game where you carefully plan your strategy or a game without any luck factoring in, Fluxx is not for you. But if you want to have a fun time with a short, random game that doesnt take itself to serious, give it a try.

in the early days of Fluxx the cards were printed black and white on heavy matte card stock that was initially impossible to shuffle and equally hard to fan out in the hand. as these things go the cards would become "looser" through repeated plays and Me and My Friends in College played the hell out of those cards. indeed, My pack was so dinged and scratched that in reality you could easily tell half the cards in the other players hands just based on the unique patterns of scratches and dents on the cards. we didn't care. the game was fun and incited good-natured ribbing and we could play a dozen hands in an evening when in reality we should have been studying a little more. I eventually played the later versions that were made of much better card-stock and maintained most of what we loved in the original and added other cards of interest. along that vector, My group of Friends also heavily modified some of our cards to add our own effects long before we ever heard of blanxx. the game just begs to be modified and made your own! don't get me wrong, i love complex and strategic games but i also love fillers like Fluxx. the world is big enough for both, and the world is better for Fluxx.
